Title: In a triangle with sides $x \le y \le z$, is it true that $P\left(\frac{x^a + z^a}{y^a} < \frac{x+z}{y}\right) = \frac{1}{a}$?
Content:
Let $x \le y \le z$ be the sides of a triangle whose vertices are uniformly distributed on a cirlce. In this question , it was proved that for any $a \ge 1$ , the probability $$
P\left(x^a + y^a > z^a\right) = \dfrac{1}{a^2}.
$$ On a similar note, experimental evidences show that there is an elegant closed formula for the probability given below for $a \ge 2$ $$
P\left(\frac{x^a + z^a}{y^a} < \frac{x+z}{y}\right) = \frac{1}{a}.
$$ Can this be proved or disproved?
AcceptedAnswer: Using argument similar to this answer , we can prove that the probability evaluates to $\frac{1}{a}$ for $a\ge 2$ . Let $$x=2\sin(\alpha+\beta),y=2\sin\alpha,z=2\sin\beta$$ With $$\alpha,\beta>0;\alpha+\beta<\pi$$ And consider $$s=\frac{z}{y}=\frac{\sin\beta}{\sin\alpha},t=\frac{x}{y}=\frac{\sin(\alpha+\beta)}{\sin\alpha}$$ The mapping $(\alpha,\beta)\mapsto(s,t)$ is bijective onto the set of pairs $(s,t)\in\mathbb{R}^2$ satisfying $$s,t>0;s+t>1>|s-t|$$ And the Jacobian determinant of the mapping is $st$ , the condition $x\le y\le z$ has Lebesgue measure $\pi^2/12$ Using the change of variable $(\alpha,\beta)\mapsto(s,t)$ , we get $$P\left(\frac{x^a+z^a}{y^a}<\frac{x+z}{y}\mid x\le y\le z\right)=\frac{12}{\pi^2}\int_{\Omega(a)}\frac{ds\,dt}{st}$$ With $$\Omega(a)=\left\{(s,t)\in\mathbb{R}^2:s\ge 1\ge t>0 ;s^a+t^a<s+t\right\}$$ Let $$s^a+t^a<s+t\implies 1\le s<u(t)$$ And $u(t)$ is the unique real root of $s^a+t^a=s+t$ . By Fubini's theorem: $$\frac{12}{\pi^2}\int_{\Omega(a)}\frac{ds\,dt}{st}=\frac{12}{\pi^2}\int_{0}^{1}\int_{1}^{u(t)}\frac{ds}{s}\frac{dt}{t}=\frac{12}{\pi^2}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln u(t)}{t}\,dt$$ Since we have $$u(t)^a+t^a=u(t)+t$$ Using idea similar to the linked post from @Tyma Gaidash (thank you so much!), we let $$t=uv,v\ge 0$$ $$\implies u^a+u^av^a=u+uv$$ $$\implies u^a\left(1+v^a\right)=u(1+v)$$ $$\implies u^{a-1}=\frac{1+v}{1+v^a}$$ $$\implies u=\sqrt[a-1]{\frac{1+v}{1+v^a}}$$ $$\implies t=v\sqrt[a-1]{\frac{1+v}{1+v^a}}$$ When $v$ runs from $0$ to $1$ , $t$ also runs from $0$ to $1$ , and $u(t)$ stays above $1$ (this is what we want) so we may do the substitution $$t=v\sqrt[a-1]{\frac{1+v}{1+v^a}}$$ $$\implies dt=-\frac{\left(v^a-av-a+1\right)\sqrt[a-1]{\frac{1+v}{1+v^a}}}{(a-1)(v+1)\left(v^a+1\right)}\,dv$$ And the probability becomes $$P\left(\frac{x^a+z^a}{y^a}<\frac{x+z}{y}\mid x\le y\le z\right)=-\frac{12}{\pi^2}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\left(v^a-av-a+1\right)\ln\sqrt[a-1]{\frac{1+v}{1+v^a}}}{v(a-1)(v+1)\left(v^a+1\right)}\,dv$$ $$=-\frac{12}{\pi^2(a-1)^2}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v(v+1)}-a\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v\left(v^a+1\right)}-\frac{\ln\left(1+v^a\right)}{v(v+1)}+a\frac{\ln\left(1+v^a\right)}{v\left(v^a+1\right)}\,dv$$ Using the idea from @Edward H (thank you so much!), we substitute $w=v^a\implies dw=av^{a-1}\,dv\implies dw/w=a\,dv/v$ into the second and fourth term. $$a\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v\left(v^a+1\right)}\,dv=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln(1+w^{1/a})}{w\left(w+1\right)}dw$$ $$a\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln(1+v^a)}{v\left(v^a+1\right)}\,dv=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln(1+w)}{w\left(w+1\right)}dw$$ $$\implies P\left(\frac{x^a+z^a}{y^a}<\frac{x+z}{y}\mid x\le y\le z\right)$$ $$=-\frac{12}{\pi^2(a-1)^2}\int_{0}^{1}2\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v(v+1)}-\frac{\ln(1+v^{1/a})}{v(v+1)}-\frac{\ln\left(1+v^a\right)}{v(v+1)}\,dv$$ $$=-\frac{12}{\pi^2(a-1)^2}\int_{0}^{1}2\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v}-\frac{\ln(1+v^{1/a})}{v}-\frac{\ln\left(1+v^a\right)}{v}\,dv\\+\frac{12}{\pi^2(a-1)^2}\int_{0}^{1}2\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v+1}-\frac{\ln(1+v^{1/a})}{v+1}-\frac{\ln\left(1+v^a\right)}{v+1}\,dv$$ As we used $\frac{1}{v(v+1)}=\frac{1}{v}-\frac{1}{v+1}$ . Consider the integral $$\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln\left(1+v^b\right)}{v}\,dv$$ With $b\ge 2$ . We substitute $w=v^b\implies dw=bv^{b-1}\implies dw/w=b\,dv/v$ $$\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln\left(1+v^b\right)}{v}\,dv=\frac{1}{b}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln\left(1+w\right)}{w}\,dw=\frac{1}{b}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{(-1)^{k-1}}{k}w^{k-1}\,dw$$ $$=\frac{1}{b}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k-1}}{k^2}=\frac{1}{b}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^2}-\frac{2}{(2k)^2}=\frac{\pi^2}{12b}$$ Thus $$-\frac{12}{\pi^2(a-1)^2}\int_{0}^{1}2\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v}-\frac{\ln(1+v^{1/a})}{v}-\frac{\ln\left(1+v^a\right)}{v}\,dv$$ $$=-\frac{12}{\pi^2(a-1)^2}\left(\frac{\pi^2}{6}-\frac{a\pi^2}{12}-\frac{\pi^2}{12a}\right)=\frac{1}{a}$$ Now we consider: $$I(a)=\int_{0}^{1}2\frac{\ln(1+v)}{v+1}-\frac{\ln(1+v^{1/a})}{v+1}-\frac{\ln\left(1+v^a\right)}{v+1}\,dv$$ Noting that $I(1)=0$ , we differentiate with respect to $a$ : $$\implies I'(a)=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{v^{1/a}\ln v}{a^2(v+1)\left(v^{1/a}+1\right)}-\frac{v^a\ln v}{(v+1)\left(v^a+1\right)}\,dv$$ For the first term, we substitute $v=w^a\implies dv=aw^{a-1}$ $$\implies \int_{0}^{1}\frac{v^{1/a}\ln v}{a^2(v+1)\left(v^{1/a}+1\right)}\,dv=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w^a\ln w}{(w+1)\left(w^a+1\right)}\,dv$$ $$\implies I'(a)=0$$ $$\implies I(a)=I(1)=0$$ Plugging all the pieces together, we obtain $$\boxed{P\left(\frac{x^a+z^a}{y^a}<\frac{x+z}{y}\mid x\le y\le z\right)=\frac{1}{a}}$$

Original_Problem:
Assumption: 
$x \le y \le z$ are the sides of a triangle,
The vertices of the triangle are uniformly distributed on a circle,
$a$ is an integer satisfying $a \ge 2$,
The probability is defined over all such triangles.
Problem: 
Prove or disprove that $$P\left(\frac{x^a + z^a}{y^a} < \frac{x+z}{y}\right) = \frac{1}{a}.$$
